sentence.text: A male infant born at 38 weeks gestation was found to have a shortened right second distal phalanx, hypoplastic nails, calcified papules on several fingers and toes, and an erythematous and alopecic depressed patch on the vertex scalp at birth (Figs. 1-4).
The pregnancy was complicated by intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR), a two-vessel cord, and maternal alcohol use in the third trimester.
After an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, the baby remained hospitalized for hypoglycemia and jaundice.
The unique constellation of findings prompted pediatric dermatology and infectious disease consultations.

At this time, examination for toxoplasmosis, other (syphilis, varicella zoster, parvovirus B19), rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes infections was negative; skeletal, cardiac, and brain imaging were performed.
A skeletal survey showed a calcified mass at the tip of the right first toe.
Echocardiogram showed a large patent ductus arteriosus and a small patent foramen ovale.

After a cranial ultrasound suggested periventricular calcifications, follow-up brain magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated periventricular mineralization and bilateral inferior temporal cortical infarcts.
Bilateral cerebral hemispheric migration anomalies, consistent with polymicrogyria, were also noted (Figs. 4 and 5).
